awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Implementation of an HBCU Undergraduate Bioinformatics Program - Lincoln University (LUBi)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Though this one-year planning project, Lincoln University will develop a minor in bioinformatics to advance knowledge in the field of bioinformatics, while training minority and underrepresented students in this growing field. This program of study would intersect chemistry/physics with biology, mathematics and computer science. Training students in interdisciplinary sciences such as bioinformatics has become more desirable, particularly with the noted underrepresentation of minorities and women in the field. Considering very few HBCUs offer undergraduate program in bioinformatics, Lincoln University is well position to contribute to diversifying the field.

Bioinformatics combines computer science, mathematics, and information technology to facilitate the collecting, organizing, and processing of large volumes of biological and chemical data. Bioinformatics concepts will be initially employed in existing biology and mathematics courses to further gauge student interest for the development of upper level, stand-alone courses. The successful implementation of a minor would serve as the premise to develop a major in bioinformatics at Lincoln University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Bioinformatics combines computer science, mathematics, and information technology in order to facilitate the collecting, organizing, and processing of large volumes of biological and chemical data. Training students in interdisciplinary sciences such as bioinformatics has become more desired; therefore, this project was prepared to implement an undergraduate bioinformatics program at Lincoln University. The overall goals of the project were: 1) Strengthen the existing STEM programs at Lincoln University by establishing a group of well-trained faculty researchers with broad expertise  2) Seeding research activities, seminars, and conducting symposium and training opportunities for students and faculty within the university as well as its collaborators. 3) Generate a pipeline of minority students who are well prepared for the workforce, and will choose to continue their education and training in STEM related disciplines.

As a result of this funding, new courses (4 courses and 3 labs) and a new minor were developed in the field of bioinformatics at Lincoln University.  The courses that were developed are: Intro to Bioinformatics (and lab), Big Data in Genomics and Proteomics (and lab), Advanced Bioinformatics (and lab), and Seminar in Bioinformatics.  These courses have been taught 3 times over the past 3 years of this grant (for a total of 16 Lincoln students now formally trained in bioinformatics from 2019-2022). The course has been expanded over the 3 years to include new topics.  The course has always focused on genomics, but in 2022, we have expanded the course to include more computer programming (Python) and robotics into the course material (using Python and robotics to analyze and prepare genomic data and samples). As of May 2022 there are 18 students who have declared a bioinformatics minor at Lincoln. One graduated in May 2020, seven graduated in May 2021, and five in 2022. Many additional students participated in summer research opportunities in bioinformatics and presented their research at local and national conferences in conjunction with this funding.

With the ever-growing interest in the multidisciplinary field of bioinformatics, now is the time to develop an academic program in bioinformatics. The bioinformatics minor has drawn from the nearly 600 students in biology, chemistry, biochemistry, engineering science, computer science, physics, mathematics, and nursing. Lincoln has started this minor with existing faculty and has garnered support and worked with the administration to hire more bioinformatics faculty over a period of 5-10 years. As the first degree granting historically black university, offering a bioinformatics minor could only be a plus for the university. Lincoln will offer courses that intersect with the current biology, chemistry, and biochemistry, curriculums, in addition to potentially drawing from the math, computer and social sciences. 

The new bioinformatics minor, as well as the new bioinformatic courses and research internships described in detail above, has provided many new educational experiences for our students at Lincoln University, both in the classroom and with hands-on active research. This effort has been successful in increasing the number of well-qualified underrepresented minority students for graduate programs in biomedical research by incorporating already established programs in STEM into the development of the Bioinformatics program.

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Carla Gallagher
